reviews.review_msg: Prof. Palys, please learn to use Canvas - one of your colleagues can teach you -it is how learning happens these days. And, why can't we have someone who is indigenous to teach about these issues? Nothing about us without us.
hes not organized at all, leaves mean comments, constant non-helpful feedback. do not recommend.

He is quite rude! His comments are not ethical when it comes to marking. And instead of providing feedback he makes fun of your work tbh! And isn't respectful no wonder why he doesn't use canvas. You can't check your grades which makes it frustrating. He asks people to speak up in class and when they do he responds aggressively

Ted is awesome! He is kind, understanding and easily reachable. The term research project wasn't too heavy and he gives you all the tools needed to do well. The paper is a bit long (15 pages) but involves little outside research. His exams are incredibly easy (all written content application questions) as long as you've at least done the readings.

A really sweet professor! The lectures may be hard to sit through sometimes but class overall wad not that difficult. 15 page paper is not bad in comparison to the ones written for other crim classes. I would recommend taking 321 with this prof.

Pretty chill professor. The class isn't too hard. Do your lecture notes and weekly readings and you will be good. Prepares you for exams very well, so please listen to his tips when he gives them. The paper may seem overwhelming because of the word count. However, it's actually doable if you start writing early. Take 321 if Ted is teaching it

Wish the instructor was more engaging... he's very very nice, but I do echo the other reviews, he's stuck in the 90's tech. Suggestion: use ahaslides, Kahoots, etc... but otherwise the content is really dull.

If you can separate the professor from the course, Ted is seriously a joy to take a class with. I can see why other students may think he's "boring", but honestly he just has a kind, calm demeanor and is working with some pretty dry content (qualitative research). Do the study questions and know them well, you'll do perfectly well in this course.

Professor Palys is an absolute sweetheart. Although his lectures can be super bland and boring. He seems to really care about what he does and his studies. The final and midterm are pretty easy as long as you pay some what attention to the material. Definitely recommend taking Ted for your CRIM 321 Mandatory.

Very passionate prof, a shame he is stuck in the 90s technology-wise. Does not use a Canvas page, and has his own website which I'm sorry is ridiculous in 2022. Lectures are long and boring, dry content goes overtime a lot. No clear guidelines for a 15-page paper, nice guy, but his disdain for using technology is frustrating when we pay for Canvas
Ted is a boring lecturer. He is nearly impossible to pay attention to with how boring the lectures are. He seems to be a nice guy. It does not help that the content is so dry.

Ted is a very nice professor and it is clear that he is very passionate about qualitative research methods. This course only had 2 exams and and a major paper so mostly you just need to keep up with your readings. Tests are all written but wasn't bad if you understand material. Also the major paper is maximum 15 pages but can be slightly shorter.

Does not use Canvas ugh uses his own website from the 90s. Does not record lectures but does post slides. Very monotone lectures and goes overtime. Exams are all based on study questions he provides for each ch of the text. Reading the text is a must. Instructions for the final paper were vague and no clue how it was graded. Tutorials not mandatory

AMAZING professor. I took Crim 429 -Indigenous peoples and international law - with him this semester and loved it. He makes the class so engaging and hes so personable and kind. He has great inclusive perspectives of the world and makes you feel really involved with the material in class. 10/10 would recommend him

It was an online class, so I have never seen him. However he is the author of the textbook and weekly modules, so I can rate him according to them. The textbook was very dry and contained a lot of useless information. His lectures were little bit more interesting, but it seems like he did not change them for at least five years.
Great guy and professor. Very reasonable and respectable as well as understanding. Tries hard to make dry material easy to understand. Glad I had this class online with Ted.

Ted is a very caring professor. There are 3 papers which are worth 25% which were marked fairly and participation which is worth 25%. He is very approachable and really cares about Indigenous issues in Canada. Overall, it was a good course.

i took this online during the summer, Ted as the actual teacher didn't do anything, the TA was sooo helpful she is the only reason i did so well. you have to rely on the textbook since no lectures, there were 2 online quizzes that were very hard, one paper with a separate proposal, and then the final which was much easier than the online quizzes

Book makes the course so much worse. Chapters are too long & dry, they don't get down to the point. Essays also take up so much time & are too long to get a direct point across. Taken online so I can't assess teaching abilities.

Ted is a genuine professor who has a passion for teaching about Indigenous peoples and the law. Although he is very knowledgable about the issues, his lectures are extremely boring. I am a student that attends every class but sitting through his lecture was brutal. He does not give clear guidelines for what he expects for the presentation or papers

Ted is the most frustrating prof I've ever had in my undergrad. He has much knowledge of indigenous leaders, history, & activism. Course material is awesome, & puts indigenous voices first as much as possible. However, his grading criteria is unclear, he's rarely in his office hours, & he doesn't like being asked questions about how he does things.

Caring, knowledgeable, soft-spoken, and extremely passionate about what he does. Majority of grade is participation, so participate! No exams, only four papers due at semester's end. Everyone who wants to understand more about indigenous issues and culture should take this class. He's a really friendly man and is easy to talk to outside of class!

Avoid the online section unless you have no choice. The textbook was super dry and very hard to read. The foundation of the final exam is based off of the text so if you don't read, prepare to fail. There are 2 quizzes; make sure you know the material - it is TIMED. Also 2 10 page papers. The TM was picky so make sure you understand the guidelines.

Took this class online. Two tests worth 15 % each and you're online given 10 minutes to answer, too rushed to complete it. Essays marked mediocre but take a long time to complete. The book is one of the most boring books ever and you have to read every chapter of it with chapters ranging from 30-40 dry pages each. would not take him again

Dr. Palys is a friendly and approachable prof. Passionate about this subject and is very willing to help. Read the textbook and review the study questions at the end of each chapter and you'll do well.

Very passionate about online privacy and ethics. Many research stories to tell that reflect the research decisions chapters in the powerpoint slides. Marks hella tough but you get some leverage with the TA marking the other half of everything. Does a good job emphasizing key points/ concepts multiple times in slides. Lectures can get a bit dry

Ted is one of those few profs that leaves a lasting impression on you: my entire view of Aboriginal-Settler issues has changed. He is knowledgeable, approachable and encouraging of questions. Grading is 25% participation and 75% essays (4 essays). There are no assignments due the whole semester and 4 (5-7pg) essays due at the end of the semester.

Ted was the first Prof in my four years at SFU that took the time to memorize every single students name. He is passionate about what he does and does it show. Participation (showing up and talking in class) counts for 25%. Rest of mark is for papers. Don't wait till the end of the course to do all the papers !

He  is a very good prof, however he tends to rant and go on long tangents.  He is not very clear when answering a question but he is there to help with anything.  Very nice guy, fairly good prof. downsides: goes on a round about way of answering things and is a little unclear on what is expected for the finial project and presentation. PARTICIPATE!

Don't need the textbook, and don't need to attend lectures.  The research project was actually a lot of fun, because you get to chose your topic.   Went to class a handful of times, worked moderately hard on my paper, and got a B-.   Just print off all the lecture slides and study them, and you'll pass and get a good mark.
He really cares about his students and is passionate about what he teaches. Would recommend.

Ted is encouraging, caring, and fair with his students. The material can be dry at times, but he's knowledgeable and well experienced in qualitative research. He makes the material interesting with real life examples and his own research projects. The term project was fair and he prepared you well for it. You learn some pretty cool stuff.

Ted is really encouraging to his students and cares about the success of everybody in his class. The material can be dry at times but his knowledge is evident and can break things down thats easy to understand. We did one big term paper that as worth 50% but he gives tons of feedback and help. Would totally take a class with him again.

Ted is a great professor and lecturer. He is knowledgeable in the fields of First Nations studies and Crim! The first paper you submit, but he only provides feedback. The next 3 assignments plus the first one are due on the last day of classes altogether, but they are assigned throughout the semester. Do not leave them to the very end!

Palys' class was a break from the usual grind. He is passionate about the material, which I personally find to always make a class easier. The content was not difficult to grasp, and I found the term research paper to be interesting and not a chore. I seriously recommend this class. Oh, and tutorials were optional (not marked).

Do not take this course. It is extremely difficult (according to the low 60's class average). The material can be hard to understand if you do not have a background or interest in research methods, but there are no recordings, videos, etc. to help in explaining the concepts. Quizzes are very detailed with limited time. Assignments are marked tough

I thought this class was going to be something totally different. Had I known what it was, I don't think I would have taken it. Ted is passionate about this stuff so tends to go on long tangents. Wish there was more class discussion. Fairly easy class if you can write.

Honestly, I was so excited to take this class but his lecture was SO BORING and dry, he gives assignments late! He's well known within the criminology department but HE SHOULDN'T TEACH!!! I didn't his class! But if you decide to take it go to every class and talk because participation is important for him. Very unorganized.
Boring. Not a Criminology class in any way. Avoid.

Great prof! Very articulate, and explained concepts well. Exams were clear cut - no tricks or anything of that sort. He was very clear about his expectations for the research paper. His course was planned out extremely well. Class could sometimes get a bit dry due to the course content, but he made it as enjoyable as it could be.
One of the best classes in my undergrad career. Ted Palys is a wonderful teacher.
Palys was one of the best profs at SFU and got me passionate about what was going on in Aboriginal Justice. Highly recommend this course b/c of its impact it had on my worldview

Well to a professor that was never at his office during office hours as given in the syllabus I can't say much positive about him.  In fact, I would go as far as to say to not use his book as referencing anyone's work.
Very interesting guest speakers! Was able to get an interesting dialogue going in the classroom every time. Amazing gift for remembering names.

Fantastic prof and class. Dr. Palys is very passionate in his lecture. Very helpful and friendly to all of us. He is very clear on what he expects in the project and the exams. Research project is fun and worthwhile to do. Rebecca is a great TA. Glad that I had a chance to take a class with Dr. P!

After not quite four years of Crim, this was the most exciting and fulfilling class I've taken. The oral history project was fascinating. Prof. Palys is just excellent -- great lecturer and very interested in his students. The project is a lot of work but very fulfilling. Very straightforward exams, too.
One of the best professors I've had at SFU.

Man this course is brutal but he does make it bearable. Midterm was easy. Paper was okay. Final was easy. His TA's are completely useless. He, however, is extremely helpful. Awesome professor with a great attitude. Overall, not bad. But bearable for a pre-req.
Palys is awesome; He helps if you ask for it. He tells you exactly what he wants for exams and term paper. I would for sure take a class with him again!

Dr. P is a great prof, but the class really sucks. His tone and material is quite boring and I dont think I learned a whole lot from the class. The paper seemed like a cake walk even though it was 20 pages. it was a very weird paper because ti didn't take form like a regular third year paper
Ted Palys is one of the most helpful instructors that I have ever had. Cares about his students and wants them to do well! Fair assignments and exams

qualitative research is confusing as it is, he asked for oral history for the term project, but even now I dont exactly know what the diffrence is between oral history and interview!!! he is very interested in the topic himself though. some lectures can be boring though the paper was not as hard as i thought, easy to fill 20 pages

I don't know why he gets such a bad rap b/c he's really not that bad. He is genuinely interested in getting to know his students and it shows.  He's a very nice, well spoken guy and does a decent job making a boring course definately bearable.
Boring, No-Humor, Not willing to help. Would not recommend taking 321 with this guy.

I really enjoyed this class. The 20 page article seems really hard at first but I really enjoyed writing it and I did quite well. When I went to Ted's office he was very helpful and seemed like a really nice guy. TA Lorinda was great! Mid-term seemed a bit tricky but final was really easy!

For someone who teaches ethics, he better have some ethics himself. I can't believe how arrogant someone can be because he has a PHD. He will probably talk about his PHD degree 100 times by the end of the semester. For those who are going to take this course: good luck because that is the only thing that can get you through his hideous character.

I cannot believe this class is mandatory, it was the biggest waste of time/credits I have ever taken. there was no textbook, only a series of journal articles, to make our lives difficult. His exams were ridiculous, and he threw us what seemed like trick questions. Nice guy though?

The class was an overall OK.  The 20-page research paper was worth half of the grade, and the exams were fairly straightforward.  Don't bother buying the textbook - completely useless. Palys is somewhat boring, but posts most of his lecture notes online.

Most boring class ever; most boring text ever. Take this class with a different prof and it might get some life. It felt like death to sit there for 2 hours a week. The text book is repetitive and not effective. The research paper was as boring to write as im sure it was to read: who cares to listen for 25 pages about a simple "life event"?
He's a nice guy and the course was not that bad. Just the lecture notes and read the book, you'll do fine. Over all - I recommend him.
His journal assignments are something else.

The comments prior to this can't possibly be from the same course/prof. This is the WORST course I've ever taken in terms of access to TM/pr and required materials. The prof's son is taking his dad's course! Conflict of interest or what! (See ch 5 of text
Wow...25 page research papers were something else, especially when they are research method papers!!
the paper was hard, kinda boring, but he was so very helpful. he wanted to see all his students do well, and he's a very nice guy.

Took Paly's Crim stats course in 1995 via distance ed. Found it extremely helpful in desiging research questions and surveys years later during my graduate course work, and now as a managing editor of medical journals.

Ted is a very laid back instructor who is very easy to approach. Although at times his lectures can get extremely boring, his midterm and final are fairly easy. Since he is the author of the textbook used, his notes are identical to his textbook material.
No Comments
Boring material, but easy class. The midterm and final were pretty much mirrored questions out of the textbook. The research paper, however, was a nightmare.
He was able to make unbeleivably boring material some what interesting. The class overall was easy but the marking between TA's was not consistent.

Ted put all his notes on pp and his website. Was clear with his explanations. But the course material itself was boring. Tests are fairly easy. Research paper was very time consuming. One TA was way too hard of a marker.
"Howie Becker, Howie Becker, Howie Becker"... God, shut up... Not a bad prof though, and the exam was kinda easy.
Ted made a boring class somewhat interesting.  Explains everything well.  The midterm was VERY EASY!0
take his class (220) by distance ed.  easiest thing i've ever done.
Ted is as laid-back a prof as you could hope for, which is good, because research is an anal discipline

Rambles forever, horrible marker, marked my project incorrectly, and i don't think he fixed it.  Lastly, he bombed people on the final, and refused to let them see it.  So I think he did that to scale the marks.
Don't ever get sick because he won't care: dropping his class or extensions are a nightmare.
